title: VC Daily: Diverging Deal and Exit Value Could Spell Market Trouble, Preqin Says
text:
Through the first eight months of this year, North American venture funds have logged a combined $238 billion in exits, writes the Preqin senior writer Charlie McGrath. Last year saw $246 billion.

Through early September, venture capitalists committed $284 billion to startups, which is nearly $100 billion more than for all of 2020. As capital invested into startups continues to rise above exit value, the market could slow down as the value of what one could sell for diverges from capital committed to a startup, Mr. McGrath wrote.

Between roughly 2013 and midway through 2019, the amount invested into startups was larger than total exit value, according to the post, but they largely moved in tandem. Currently, the two figures are diverging.

"Exit activity may still be far above historical norms, but it's cooling off, and meanwhile deal values have escalated sharply, which could catch up with and temper hopes of future outperformance," Mr. McGrath wrote.

And now on to the news...

Top News

New fundraise. Addition LP, a venture firm launched by former Tiger Global Management investor Lee Fixel in 2019, is raising its third fund, WSJ Pro's Yuliya Chernova reports, citing people familiar with the situation.

Mr. Fixel had raised one of the largest debut funds in venture capital history when he collected $1.28 billion for Addition One LP last year. He quickly followed with Addition Two LP of the same size, according to a regulatory filing. Mr. Fixel is now raising as much or more for the third fund, the people said. A representative of Addition declined to comment.

While Addition is a very young firm, it has already seen one of its companies go public. Montevideo, Uruguay-based payments company dLocal, which Addition backed in a financing last year that valued the company at $1.2 billion, went public in June and is now trading at a market capitalization of more than $18 billion.

Ginkgo Bioworks Goes Public After Closing SPAC Merger

Shares of synthetic-biology company Ginkgo Bioworks Holdings Inc. rose on their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, following the closing of its merger with a blank-check company, WSJ Pro's Brian Gormley reports. Boston-based Ginkgo on Friday completed a merger with Soaring Eagle Acquisition Corp. and started trading under the ticker symbol DNA. Ginkgo shares opened at $11.15 apiece and ended regular trading at $12.18. Ginkgo raised more than $1.6 billion through the transaction, which valued the company at $15 billion. Ginkgo uses tools such as robotics, software and data analytics to genetically program cells to produce compounds for applications in areas such as food ingredients, fragrances, cosmetics and medications. Its pitch to customers is that synthetic biology techniques can reduce the time and cost of product development and enable goods to be produced more sustainably.

Atlantic Street Capital Targets $850 Million for New Fund

Lower-midmarket-focused Atlantic Street Capital Management is targeting $850 million for its fifth fund, according to people familiar with the fundraising, WSJ Pro reports. If the Greenwich, Conn.-based firm reaches the target, Atlantic Street Capital V LP would be 70% larger than its predecessor, which wrapped up with $500 million in 2019. The Los Angeles County Employees Retirement Association, a public pension system that manages $71.49 billion, committed up to $150 million to the latest fund, according to documents from the pension system.

Industry News

IPO Tracking

DevOps platform provider GitLab Inc. filed for an initial public offering. The company's venture backers include GV, Khosla Ventures and Iconiq Capital. GitLab has applied to list on the Nasdaq Global Market under the symbol GTLB.

Funds

Growth investor 3TS Capital Partners held a first close for its fourth flagship fund. The Helsinki-based firm invests €5 million to €20 million, equivalent to about $5.9 million to $23.6 million, in expanding technology companies and aims to raise €150 million for Fund IV.

Matchstick Ventures raised $55 million for its third fund to continue making pre-seed and seed-stage investments in technology startups with a connection to the Rockies and the Northern regions of the U.S. The firm recently participated in funding rounds for healthcare digital marketing and customer relationship management platform Cured, and Branch, which helps businesses accelerate payments to workers.

People

AI-focused Radical Ventures named Rob Toews as partner and David Katz as operating partner. Mr. Toews was previously at Highland Capital Partners. Mr. Katz was most recently at Benecaid. Toronto-based Radical Ventures also appointed Ryan Shannon as a full-time investment team member, and promoted Parasvil Patel and Blair Bernholtz to partner.

European business-to-business software investor Dawn Capital promoted Evgenia Plotnikova to general partner. Prior to joining the firm in 2018, Ms. Plotnikova spent several years at Atomico and TPG.

Sendbird Inc., a mobile engagement and communication platform, hired Sam Zayed as chief revenue officer. Mr. Zayed comes to Sendbird from Conga, where he served as CRO. Earlier this year, San Mateo, Calif.-based Sendbird raised a $100 million Series C round from Steadfast Financial, Emergence Capital, Softbank Vision Fund 2, Iconiq Capital, Tiger Global Management and Meritech Capital.

Exits

Tokyo-based JSR Corp. agreed to purchase extreme ultraviolet lithography company Inpria Corp. for $514 million. Based in Corvallis, Ore., Inpria is backed by investors including Samsung Ventures, Air Liquide Venture Capital, Applied Ventures and Intel Capital.

Hinge Health Inc., a digital physical therapy platform for the treatment of back and joint pain, acquired wrnch, developer of a computer vision platform for measuring human motion, for an undisclosed amount. Early this year, Hinge raised a $300 million Series D round at a $3 billion valuation. Investors included Coatue Management, Tiger Global, Atomico, Insight Partners and Bessemer Venture Partners.

New Money

Omaze Inc., a Culver City, Calif.-based social impact fundraising platform, landed $85 million in Series C funding. Moore Strategic Ventures led the round, which included contributions from FirstMark Capital, Wndrco, Telstra Ventures, Causeway Media Partners, Mockingbird Ventures, Bertelsmann Digital Media Investments and Pegasus Ventures. James McIntyre, senior managing director and chief operating officer of Moore Strategic Ventures, will join Omaze's board.

Amolyt Pharma, a France- and Cambridge, Mass.-based startup developing therapeutic peptides for rare endocrine and related diseases, closed an $80 million Series B round. Co-led by Sectoral Asset Management and Andera Partners, the investment included participation from ATEM Capital, LSP, Novo Holdings, Kurma Partners, Mass General Brigham Ventures, Bpifrance, Orbimed, Pontifax Venture Capital, Eurazeo and others.

Rewind, a Canada-based builder of apps that protect critical Saas and cloud data, completed a $65 million Series B round. Insight Partners led the funding, which saw additional support from Atlassian Ventures, Bessemer Venture Partners, FundFire, Inovia Capital, Ridge Ventures, ScaleUp Ventures and Union Ventures. John True of Insight Partners will join the board.

Mynd, an Oakland, Calif.-based single-family rental investment startup, grabbed a $57.3 million funding round from QED Investors.

Abra, a wealth management platform for cryptocurrency investors, nabbed $55 million in Series C funding. Lead investors Ignia and Blockchain Capital were joined by Lerer Hippeau, Arbor Ventures, RRE Ventures and others in the round.

Anjarium Biosciences AG, a Switzerland-based startup focused on creating a new class of non-viral gene therapies, collected 55.5 million Swiss Francs ($61 million) in Series A funding. Abingworth and Gimv led the investment, which included contributions from Omega Funds, Pfizer Ventures and Surveyor Capital.

Sleeper, a fantasy sports startup, scored $40 million in Series C funding led by Andreessen Horowitz.

The Org, provider of a network of public org charts for employees at startups, raised $20 million in Series B funding. Tiger Global Management led the round, which included participation from Sequoia Capital, Founders Fund, Balderton Capital and Thursday Ventures.

Othram Inc., a The Woodlands, Texas-based DNA laboratory helping law enforcement to crack unresolved cases, secured $18 million in Series B financing. Gigafund led the round, with Managing Partner Stephen Oskoui joining the company's board.

9am.health Inc., an Encinitas, Calif.-based virtual diabetes clinic, launched with $3.7 million in seed funding from Founders Fund, Define Ventures, Speedinvest and iSeed Ventures.

Aircover Inc., a San Mateo, Calif.-based sales intelligence platform, was seeded with a $3 million investment. Defy Partners led the round, which included additional support from Firebolt Ventures, Flex Capital and Ridge Ventures. Bob Rosin of Defy Partners will join the board.

Tech News

U.S. to target crypto ransomware payments with sanctions

How Facebook hobbled Mark Zuckerberg's bid to get America vaccinated

‘Dark stores': How groceries are being delivered in minutes

China's Tencent says it will make it easier to share links to rivals on WeChat

What the Elizabeth Holmes trial is revealing about Theranos
